reviewText: The silent 1925 classic "Ben Hur" is one of the greatest films ever made, and when watching the famous chariot race, I am always reminded that no matter how advanced filmmaking has become with its technological wizardry, no action sequence had ever matched what director Fred Niblo managed to achieve in that sequence. The film suffered through many production problems, taking years to film, with a change of directors and star, and was the most expensive film of its time, costing $ 4,000.000, which was a fortune in those days, but fortunately, also became the third largest grossing silent film ever made. One of the many reasons for the excessive cost was the innovative use of 2-strip Technicolor, a fabulous predecessor to the 3-strip Technicolor I like so much in the sword-and-sandal epics of the '50s, and it is sumptuously used to accentuate certain scenes, like the nativity, and the triumphant entrance into Rome.Ramon Novarro is brilliant as Judah Ben Hur, and it is no doubt the best film of this great actor's career. Rudolph Valentino paved the way for a Latin to become a leading man, and Novarro, of Mexican birth, achieved stardom soon after Valentino, and there are many comparisons between the two actors. His expressive subtlety is rare in the silent film genre, and is superb in scenes of romantic conflict, as in the "seduction scene", when Messala's woman is trying to find out Judah's identity. Small of stature, he nevertheless had a sturdy physique that enabled him to carry off the action scenes well, and his beautiful, classic features were much loved by the camera.One of the main reasons that this film is such a gratifying experience is the adaptation by June Mathis of Lewis Wallace's book. Reading the cards is a pleasure, as they are well written in a graceful prose. Mathis incidentally, was instrumental in making Valentino a leading man, as she fought for him to be cast in her 1921 "The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse", a film that Novarro was an "extra" in, as a guest at a ball.The score by Carl Davis is also marvelous, and adds much to this magnificent epic.Comparing this film to the 1959 William Wyler version is interesting, but neither "is better" than the other, both being masterpieces of their respective eras, and two of the finest examples of cinematic artistry ever made.If you appreciate great filmmaking, this silent classic is not to be missed; total running time is 148 minutes.

reviewText: In 1925, Fred Niblo (and other directors) created several moments in BEN-HUR: A TALE OF THE CHRIST that were reference points for William Wyler's '59 remake.An action sequence that couldn't be duplicated or exceeded was the naval battle. In this silent version, a real boat rams the trireme that Judah is imprisoned on. Its hull collapses, water rushes in and more than one Italian extra nearly drowns in the resulting chaos.One impressive technique was using Technicolor for any scenes related to Jesus. In Wyler's picture all cinematography is color. The dramatic contrast between the presence or influence of Christ and his b&w; absence is lost. Never showing his face IS retained, though.Studio execs concerned with a snail's pace shoot and major expenses in Italy brought the partly completed movie back to Hollywood. The famous chariot race was shot in California, which is why so many actors, directors and other celebrity spectators are listed at imdb as uncredited extras. An undercranked camera makes this sequence unusually speedy and spoils its impact, IMO.As for this Korean import of the silent "Hur," it's transferred from less-than-perfect stock that reveals damage in spots (thus my 1 star rating).A beautiful dub of the '25 epic is a bonus offering on WARNER'sBEN-HUR Four Disc Collector's Edition.As the Romans say: Caveat emptor!

reviewText: With the record number of Oscars won by the William Wyler 1959 version of BEN-HUR, there is a tendency to overlook the monumental 1925 production, which established MGM as a studio to be reckoned with. Well, if you've never seen the earlier version, you may be in for a surprise...it is as enjoyable in nearly every way!Certainly, some of the performances (particularly Francis X. Bushman's scenery-chewing Messala) are cartoonish, the film lacks the widescreen splendor and scope of it's successor, and the 'Wyler Touch', the infinite care the legendary director poured over every detail, is sorely missed. But the 1925 production, beset by so many problems that it became the most expensive film ever made, brought new production head Irving Thalberg into the limelight, and his first decision was brilliant, firing the current director, and bringing in veteran director Fred Niblo to take charge. Niblo brought an energy and sense of intimacy to the silent "Ben-Hur" that is actually often lacking in the later version. The finished film, as a whole, is far closer in spirit to General Lew Wallace's novel, and young leading man Ramon Novarro (with a sexy intensity reminiscent of Tyrone Power), makes a far more charismatic and sympathetic Ben-Hur than Charlton Heston's more iconic portrayal.The 1959 version is remembered today primarily for the chariot race, one of the most spectacular action sequences ever filmed. But what of the other 'set piece', the gigantic sea battle between the Roman and pirate fleets? The scene is patently artificial, obviously comprised of model ships in a tank and rear projections (watch the tiny toy seamen jiggle as ships collide!) The 1925 version's chariot race is fast-paced and certainly exciting, and the sea battle is astonishing, using full-sized ships and hundreds of extras (shot in Italy, where an actual fire broke out on the ships during the battle...the extras' panic onscreen was NOT acting...)With an early two-strip Technicolor to emphasize key scenes (the Nativity, the new Roman Consul's arrival in Jerusalem...yes, those ARE topless women leading the procession!), and a wonderful, stirring new musical score by Carl Davis, Fred Niblo's BEN-HUR is a treasure, a film certainly worthy to stand beside the 1959 version!

reviewText: Compared to many other silent films, the 1925 production of Ben Hur was a stunning achievement, epic in every way. The naval battle in particular is quite impressive, and the chariot race is for its time.CONS:While there is much gushing about the chariot race in this version being superior to the race in Heston's version, I just cannot agree. Certainly it was an impressive piece of action for 1925. However, there are far too many close-ups of Ben Hur and Massala in front of rear projected images, all of which are extremely fuzzy, since they had to be blown up so large. The fact that the action had to be periodically interrupted to show dialog cards also spoils the pace of the sequence. Frankly, the lack of sound is a further drawback, as the sound of those thundering hooves helps to drive the action in the later film.Another drawback to the version is the nature of acting in the silent era. Every expression and motion had to be overplayed to make up for the absence of dialog. Sometimes this works artistically, sometimes it just looks silly. For example, after Massala is seriously injured near the end of the race, his Egyptian lover is shown emoting in her box seat. If not for the context, you would be hard pressed to describe whether she is grieving or laughing!Ramon Navarro is a far cry from Charlton Heston as the image of Ben Hur. He has a decidedly soft and wimpy look to him which makes his supposed acts of physical strength somewhat dubious. It was actually pretty humorous to see this short, slightly pudgy guy making things tough on four Roman captors. LOL Leprosy is portrayed by a bit of an extra smudge of eye shadow beneath the eyes and some dark rouge under the cheekbones.PROS:With my "cons" out of the way, there are plenty of "pros" about this film as well, and thus the reason for my good number of stars. The acting is generally quite good within the scope possible in a silent feature. The color sequences are surprising for a film of its time. When I first saw this film I didn't know it had color, and indeed didn't know that color had even been attempted in a mass market film of that time. I wondered if it was a gimmick of later restoration until I did some research. Sets are large, detailed, and immensely impressive. This ships constructed for the naval battle must have cost a small fortune just in themselves.This version has a significant motif left out of the later version ... Ben Hur raising two legions to do war with the Romans in the name of the new King.Sadly, the limitations of this movie were brought on by the technology of its time, and nothing more. Without sound for dialog, Navarro has no chance of portraying the emotion that Heston brought to the role, an emotion which I think is essential to bringing home to the audience his love of family, despair at their loss, and joy at their eventual reunion and salvation.

reviewText: The silent version of Ben-Hur produced by the newly formed Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is a first rate epic.  It was dogged by disaster: the replacement of the director (Fred Niblo took over), the actor playing Ben-Hur (George Walsh) and much of the location shot footage (done in Italy) was unusable.  A warehouse fire destroyed many of the props.  The production was moved from Italy back to the United States and, thanks to Irving Thalberg, the movie was an enormous success establishing MGM as the top movie studio.It is indeed interesting to see how much the remake in the 50's borrowed from the 1925 version.  The silent version, for me, has the better (and more violent) sea battle sequence, and although the chariot race (on which Thalberg spent $300,000) may not as spectacular as the 1959 version it is very well done.  When Messala's chariot looses a wheel he is hit by three other drivers, which made quite an impressive stunt.The budget for this version of Ben-Hur came to $3.9 million, a fortune in the 1920's but the money is on the screen.  Francis X Bushman may be a little hammy but he is an effective villein.  Ramon Navarro makes a heroic, yet vulnerable, Ben-Hur.

reviewText: Although it has its failings--most notably a very "grand manner" performance by Francis X. Bushman as Messala--this silent epic holds up extremely well, and viewers familiar with only the later Heston version will be amazed at how much the remake borrowed (sometimes shot for shot) from the original.  This is particularly true of the famous chariot race scene, of which the sound version offers a rather tame version in comparison.Bushman aside (it would be his last major film), and with a few exceptions in various scenes scattered through the movie, the cast generally plays with considerable restraint; consequently, BEN-HUR is a silent movie very accessible to those who have had little experience with silent film.  Ramon Navorro is particularly effective in the title role, and unlike the remake gives us a youthful, handsome, and curiously innocent portrait of Juda Ben-Hur.  The sets and big-scale action sequences are expertly done.  An excellent choice for a silent-movie fan or any one looking to begin an exploration of this period in cinema.

reviewText: "Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ", without a doubt would have to go down into cinematic history as one of the most ambitious film productions undertaken during the whole silent era. Much has been written and discussed about this legendary film from its totally chaotic filming that resembles that other gigantic Hollywood epic, 1963's "Cleopatra", to the great star making role it provided for top silent screen actor Ramon Novarro after first choice Rudolph Valentino missed out. For me "Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ", is both a superb cinematic viewing experience from Hollywood's early era as well as a moving, and beautifully acted story of faith and its endurance under often trying circumstances. Remade of course in 1959 also by MGM this earlier version has all its own unique qualities to appreciate and it stands the test of time excellentlyBased on the famous 1880 novel by  Lew Wallace, a Broadway version had preceeded this ambitious attempt at filming this gigantic story. The well chronicled filming took a number of years to complete after numerous rewrites, cast and location changes and financial crisis helped make it the most expensive movie made up to that time and was the film that almost sank the newly merged Metro-Goldwyn and Mayer Studio. Out of this chaos however emerged a sensational motion picture unsurpassed for majesty and excitment with Mexican actor Ramon Novarro making the role of the young Jewish prince cast out into the harsh world his own and winning everlasting stardom with his terrific performance. Novarro plays Judah Ben-Hur, the innocent only son of a wealthy Jewish family in first century Jerusalem. Judah and his family like everyone else are being oppressed by the occupying Roman Forces . He encounters his old friend but now potential enemy Messala (Francis X. Bushman), who after many years away has returned now as a Roman Centurion with definite views on the inferiority of the Jewish population to the all conquering Romans. Judah and Messala clash and Messala warns him to keep a low profile with his controversial views on Jewish freedom etc. However during a parade when the new Roman Governor is passing through the streets Judah accidently dislodges a tile which falls and kills the official. Messala now enacts his revenge and Judah is enslaved to work on the Galleys and his mother and daughter (Claire McDowell and Kathleen Kay respectively), are cast out into the world with nothing to support them. Judah endures starvation, cruelty and the death of those around him through three brutal years as a galley slave. His body becomes broken however never once does his spirit or faith leave him. When the Galley is attacked by pirates Judah finds himself adrift with the ship's commander Quintus Arrius (Frank Currier), who took pity on him and admired Judah's strength under horrific circumstances. In gratitude for him saving his life Arrius frees Judah from the bonds of slavery and makes him his adapted son. Judah enjoys the rich bounty of life in Rome but never stops searching for his lost loved ones who he convinces himself are still alive. Hearing of the possible whereabouts of the former servant of the House of Hur Simonides (Nigel De Brulier), who safeguarded the Hur fortune entrusted to him by Judah's mother even after torture by the Romans, Judah sets out for Antioch to find him. Finding the now aged Simonides, Judah also makes the reacquaintance after many years with his daughter Esther (May McAvoy) and discovers his passion for her sweet innocence undiminished. Judah however also encounters his old nemesis Messala and too settle the score once and for all with the man who ruined his family Judah agrees to compete in the chariot race being held at the Antioch Arena the next day coming into direct oppostiion with the hated Messala. Despite every ploy to destroy Judah during the race which the whole city turns out to see Messala pays for his arrogance with his life and Judah triumphs as the greatest chariot racer the city has ever seen. Despite this acclaim Judah now sets out to find his mother and sister and it is Esther who finds out the shocking truth that both women are now suffering from leprosy. Again at a time when Judah's faith is put to the test the appearance of Jesus of Nazareth in his life , this time on his way to his own crucifixion, not only heals the women of their terrible affliction but once again restores Judah's faith in God and mankind."Peerless", is how I would describe this ground breaking production and as is so often with productions that experience chaotic production histories none of it shows in the finished product. Ramon Novarro had the role of a life time as Judah Ben-Hur and he gives a performance of both rare sensitivity and inner stength. This was a star making role if ever there was one and although this talented actor gave many great performances both before and after "Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ", this is the role for which he is rightfully remembered. Francis X. Bushman delivers a very old style performance as the evil Messala which in some respects has not aged that well but he is highly effective in the climatic chariot race. Other performances by May McAvoy as the sweet Esther, Claire McDowell as Judah's mother, Nigel De Brulier as Simonides and Carmel Myers as the seductive Iras all add a wonderful colour to the proceedings. "Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ", abounds with sensational action pieces such as the justly famous chariot race which is still unsurpassed for amazing photography and stunt work. The huge sea battle between the Roman army and the pirates which was filmed off the coast of Italy would have to go down as one of the best of its kind ever filmed. The use of innovative two strip technicolour sequences at various intervals in the story including the lengthy prologue detailing the birth of Christ, are truly magnificent and have been restored to the existing print in the recent restoration of this classic by Kevin Brownlow. A highly appropriate new musical score composed and conducted by Carl Davis using the London Philharmonic Orchestra has also been added to the production which aids greatly during the climatic moments in the story.Most movie goers of course are far more familiar with the more readily available 1959 remake also by MGM of "Ben-Hur", however this version makes an interesting contrast to the later effort in particular in how the character of Judah Ben-Hur is played by Ramon Novarro and by Charlton Heston in the remake. I find this 1926 silent version with sound effects added to be a viewing experience to cherish and it is one of the few occasions nowadays where the great acting skills of the legendary Ramon Novarro can be widely appreciated. At two and a half hours long this version is a real epic however you dont have to be a silent film buff to enjoy "Ben-Hur: A Tale of the Christ", it is a moving and beautifully played classic that you are sure to get alot out of.
summary: Unforgettable Silent Masterpiece Based On A Classic Story
